H0.text: Diamonds have sharp edges, as demonstrated by the observation that a diamond was able to scratch a piece of talc.

H1.text: Talc is softer than diamonds because students observed that a diamond was able to scratch a piece of talc.

H2.text: Diamonds are very valuable, because students observed that a diamond was able to scratch a piece of talc.

H3.text: Talc and diamonds are both minerals, as evidenced by students observing that a diamond was able to scratch a piece of talc.

A4.text: Diamond was the hardest known naturally occurring mineral when the scale was designed, and defines the top of the scale, arbitrarily set at 10.

A5.text: Minerals are chemically pure solids found in nature.

A6.text: Diamond is a solid form of pure carbon with its atoms arranged in a crystal structure called diamond cubic.

A7.text: These tend to result in extremely flat, highly polished facets with exceptionally sharp facet edges.

A8.text: The Mohs scale of mineral hardness, based on scratch hardness comparison, defines value 1 as the hardness of talc, the softest mineral.
